Special case www.123done.org -> prod

Special case www.123done.org -> prod

Previously, only the bare domain was supported, and www.123done.org would try to
load from www.personatest.org, which is unlikely to be what we want.

Adding special case for native-persona.org

Move the github ribbon down in the page

This button is the first thing that shows up in the list of
available links that screen readers produce. Moving it down the
page will allow users to find the login button more quickly.

Add alt text to the sign in button

Without this textual representation, the button is not really
visible to screen readers or to people who have images turned off.
Use loggedInUser instead of loggedInEmail (fixes mozilla/123done#49)

Push scripts to the bottom and defer loading

To prevent a front-end single-point of failure and speed up
rendering of the page, I think that should be the recommended way
of setting up Persona.

Merge pull request mozilla/fxa-auth-server#114 from dannycoates/hawkKey

Clarify splitting {session,keyFetch}Token into id and reqHMACKey

token.key should be a Buffer, but stored as hex

token.key is used by Hawk as the HMAC key. If its
a Buffer, it uses those bytes, if its a string Hawk
converts the it to a Buffer with UTF8 encoding. We
want Hawk to use the "raw" bytes. This was discovered
in mozilla/fxa-auth-server#114

docs: email should be hex-encoded UTF-8, to avoid ambiguity

If we sent it as raw unicode, then it would get encoded by the HTTP
agent, decoded by the server's HTTP stack, then delivered through who
knows what to the IDP application code. Each step is an opportunity for
something to go wrong and mangle the string, which would break the
key-derivation being done by both sides. It's safest to encode it
exactly once, at the beginning, according to our API spec, and send only
boring ASCII over the wire.

update API: include all SRP/stretching parameters, change salt names

If we update the code to implement these APIs, we'll be able to deliver
all the stretching/salting information the client needs. The current API
spec is too limited in some places (only delivering one number for
stretching, when actually we need 5 plus a type, and overspecified in
others (naming a hash algorithm and group-size-in-bits for SRP, when
really it should just be a single name for the whole parameter set).

I'd recommend calling the SRP salt "srpSalt" rather than "s". There is a
different SRP object named (capital) "S", which absolutely must be kept
secret (it is the derived shared key), and using the same letter for
both is bound to confuse somebody down the line into publishing "S" by
mistake, which would be disastrous.

Feel free to fix the spelling (e.g. scryptN instead of scrypt_N), I
don't know what the local conventions are.
